title: Requires certain pedestrian crosswalks and ramps to be clearly marked and painted in N.Y. city
summary: Requires certain pedestrian crosswalks and ramps, those not located at street intersections, to be clearly marked and painted in any city with a population of one million or more.
fulltext:
S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                          816

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                 I N  A S S E M B L Y

                                      (PREFILED)

                                    January 5, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by M. of A. DINOWITZ, BRENNAN, MILLMAN -- Multi-Sponsored by
         -- M. of A. CLARK, GLICK, MARKEY, ORTIZ,  PHEFFER  --  read  once  and
         referred to the Committee on Cities

       AN  ACT  to  amend  the  administrative code of the city of New York, in
         relation to clearly marking certain pedestrian crosswalks in any  city
         having a population of one million or more persons

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The administrative code of the city of New York is  amended
    2  by adding a new section 19-112.1 to read as follows:
    3    S 19-112.1 MARKING CERTAIN PEDESTRIAN CROSSWALKS AND RAMPS. ALL PEDES-
    4  TRIAN  CROSSWALKS  AND RAMPS, NOT LOCATED AT STREET INTERSECTIONS, SHALL
    5  BE CLEARLY MARKED AND PAINTED. THIS PROVISION SHALL APPLY  TO  BOTH  NEW
    6  AND RECONSTRUCTED CROSSWALKS AND RAMPS.
    7    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.






        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD04335-01-1
actClause: AN ACT to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to clearly marking certain pedestrian crosswalks in any city having a population of one million or more persons
